entries.tagline: A powerful story about individuality, rebellion and poetry at a strict boys' school.
entries.fullText:
Dead Poets Society is one of those stories that hits you right in the chest if you've ever felt out of place in a system that wants you to be quiet, obedient and predictable.

Through Mr. Keating and his students, the book explores how art and poetry can be acts of resistance. It's about friendship, grief, and the risk of living a life that is actually yours, not the one others designed for you.

If you like emotional, character-driven stories with atmosphere and a bit of heartbreak, this is basically required reading.

entries.tagline: Dark academia, obsession and a Greek-class gone very wrong.
entries.fullText: The Secret History is the darker, colder cousin of Dead Poets Society. Same campus feeling, very different moral compass.

entries.tagline: Intimate, messy, painfully honest relationship study.
entries.fullText: Normal People is about two people who can't quite stay away from each other and can't quite get it right either.

entries.tagline: Epic sci-fi politics, sandworms, and prophecy.
entries.fullText: Dune is huge, slow-burn and extremely satisfying if you like dense worlds and power games.

entries.tagline: A warning disguised as a novel. Uncomfortable and essential.
entries.fullText: 1984 still feels uncomfortably close to home. That's exactly why it belongs here.

entries.tagline: Chaotic, absurd, deeply comforting sci-fi humour.
entries.fullText: Hitchhike through the Galaxy is the "it's all ridiculous anyway, might as well laugh" book of the list.
